content: How can I help you today?
I'm not really sure how to start… things have been really hard at home, and I’ve been struggling to keep it all together. My wife wanted me to come, but I’m honestly not sure how much this will help.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like there's been a lot on your plate, and it’s understandable to feel unsure about how this might help. It’s great that you’re here, though—it shows a lot of strength to take this step. Would you like to share more about what's been going on at home or what brought you here today?

Well, my son has been having some serious behavioral problems, and my wife and I can't figure out how to help him. It's been really stressful, and it's gotten to the point where it's putting a strain on our marriage. I just feel like everything is unraveling, and I don’t know what to do anymore.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming—trying to support your son while also feeling the weight it’s putting on your marriage. It seems like you’re carrying a lot right now, and it’s been hard to find a way forward. What has this been like for you, trying to manage all of this at once?

It’s been absolutely exhausting. I feel like I’m failing as a dad when I can’t help my son, and then I feel like I’m failing as a husband too because my wife and I just keep arguing over what to do. I can’t focus at work, and I don’t even enjoy anything anymore. It’s like everything’s slipping away.

That sounds really heavy—it’s clear how much you care about your family and want to be there for them, but all of this responsibility and conflict is leaving you worn out and disconnected from the things you once enjoyed. It’s a lot to navigate all at once. What keeps you going despite everything you’re feeling right now?

I guess what keeps me going is really my family, as broken as it feels right now. I want to help my son get better, I want to fix things with my wife, and I want to be present for my daughter too. I just don’t know how to make it all work when I feel like I’m running on empty.

Your love for your family really shines through, even in the middle of all this difficulty. You’re holding onto what matters most to you, even when it feels like there’s no clear path forward—that’s a strong commitment. It sounds like you’re feeling stuck between wanting to give them everything you can and needing to figure out how to take care of yourself, too. What do you think would help you feel less overwhelmed right now?

Honestly, I don’t even know. I feel like I’m so far in it that I can’t even see what might help. Maybe... if I could just feel like I wasn’t failing all the time, or like there were small ways to make progress, that might take some of the weight off. But honestly, I don’t feel very hopeful about anything working.

It’s understandable that feeling stuck and overwhelmed might make it hard to see a way forward, especially when you’ve been trying so hard and nothing seems to be getting better. Wanting to feel like you’re making even small steps of progress makes a lot of sense—it could be a way to remind yourself that change is possible, even if it feels distant right now. What would “a small step” look like for you, if you could imagine one?

I really don’t know—it’s hard to even imagine what a small step would look like right now. Maybe something like figuring out how to help my son in some way or finding a way to have a real conversation with my wife without it turning into an argument. But even thinking about those feels like a lot.

It sounds like even small steps feel overwhelming right now, especially with how much is going on. At the same time, you’re identifying some meaningful areas—helping your son and strengthening your connection with your wife—that seem really important to you. What’s helped you in the past when things have felt this heavy? Have you had moments, even small ones, where you’ve felt a bit more hopeful or connected?

I'm not sure anything has really helped lately. It feels like I'm just stuck in this constant cycle of stress and frustration. Maybe small moments where my wife and I aren’t arguing, or when I can get my son to laugh, but those moments feel so rare. Honestly, I’ve forgotten what it feels like to just breathe and not feel all this weight on me.

It sounds like the weight of everything has been so constant that it’s hard to even remember those lighter moments, though it’s clear those small instances of connection—like your son’s laughter or peaceful times with your wife—mean a lot to you. Even if they feel rare, they show there’s something there that you value deeply. How do you think it might feel to experience more of those moments, even just little by little?

I think it would feel reassuring, like maybe things aren’t completely lost and there’s still something to hold onto. But honestly, I don’t know how to create more of those moments with everything else taking over. It feels impossible to get to a place where those moments aren’t just rare exceptions.

It sounds like those moments bring some hope and connection, even though right now they feel few and far between. It’s tough to think about creating more of them when the weight of everything else feels so overwhelming. What do you think might make it easier to find even one of those moments, or to notice them when they happen?

It’s hard to even think about that when everything feels so heavy. Maybe if I could slow down or stop feeling so drained all the time, I’d have more space to notice those moments or make them happen. But I honestly don’t know how to get there—it feels like I’m so far away from that right now.

Feeling drained and weighed down makes it so hard to even imagine finding that space to slow down or be present—it’s a tough place to be in. But it sounds like having that space could help you feel a little more open to noticing and creating those moments you value so much. What’s one thing, no matter how small, that might help you even begin to take a breath or feel less weighed down?

Maybe just getting a little bit of time for myself, even if it’s just a walk or sitting quietly without everything pressing on me. But then I feel guilty stepping away because there’s so much going on—it’s hard to even let myself take that break.

It’s understandable to feel torn—on one hand, knowing that a moment for yourself could help, and on the other, feeling guilty for stepping away when everything feels so demanding. It sounds like caring for your family is so important to you, but part of you recognizes that taking just a little time to recharge could make a difference. What would it mean for you, and maybe even for your family, if you gave yourself permission to take that small, restorative moment?
